quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The way I learned how to pitch in business school, and I think the way most people did is what I call the arrogant doctor.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Names the common default pitch pattern so practitioners can recognize and move beyond it.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: So you have a problem, a pain, I have a solution, a treatment, and I'm going to tell you why it's better than all the other treatments.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Summarizes the conventional problem-solution-brag structure that strategic narrative aims to replace.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Every movie starts with some kind of shift in the world, and I call this shift the shift from the old game to a new game.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Introduces a transferable storytelling model: lead with a world change that reframes the audience’s situation.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The archetypal example of this, I think in the business world, is what Benioff did with Salesforce.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Points to a concrete, well-known example of the “old game to new game” narrative in action.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: This structure really is about defining a movement, and that's very different from, "Hey, I'm going to solve your problem."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Contrasts movement-building narratives with standard solution pitching, reframing what persuasive messaging should do.

quotes.topic_title: Podcast intro: Andy and strategic narrative
quotes.text: Andy helps CEOs and company leaders align their teams around something he calls a strategic narrative, which as you'll learn all about in this episode, is essentially a simple story that helps people understand why they need your product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Defines the core framework—using a “strategic narrative” as a simple story to clarify product value and drive alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Podcast intro: Andy and strategic narrative
quotes.text: And with that helps you align your sales, marketing, and product teams along with your fundraising and even your hiring efforts.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights the practical, cross-functional leverage of a narrative beyond product and marketing into fundraising and hiring.

quotes.topic_title: Podcast intro: Andy and strategic narrative
quotes.text: Andy has worked closely with some of the most successful founders and companies out there, including companies like Gong, Dropbox, Uber, Salesforce, Square, IBM, and many others.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides specific examples that establish credibility and show the approach is used across top-tier companies.

quotes.topic_title: Podcast intro: Andy and strategic narrative
quotes.text: Andy explains why most people are pitching their product completely wrong, why focusing on the problem you're solving for people is no longer an effective pitch and how the strategic narrative helps you frame your solution in a much more effective way.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A counterintuitive claim that challenges “problem-first” pitching and points to narrative framing as a more effective method.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I use Coda every day to wrangle my newsletter content calendar, my interview notes for podcasts, and to coordinate my sponsors.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of using a single tool to manage multiple operational workflows end-to-end.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: they shared a dozen templates that they use internally to run their product team, including managing a roadmap, their OKR process, getting internal feedback, and essentially their whole product development process is done within Coda.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Specific, replicable operating model: standardize core product processes via reusable templates in one system.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If your team's work is spread out across different documents and spreadsheets and a stack of workflow tools, that's why you need Coda.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable diagnostic for tool sprawl: fragmentation is a signal to consolidate into a single source of truth.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Coda puts data in one centralized location regardless of format, eliminating roadblocks that can slow your team down.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Operational principle: centralize cross-format data to reduce coordination overhead and execution friction.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Thousands of people apply to join this collective, and I personally review and accept just about 10% of them.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Notable data point on curation/selectivity that signals quality control in a talent marketplace.

quotes.topic_title: Andy’s origin story: from coder to narrative
quotes.text: One VC wrote back and said, "Listen, I rate every plan I get on a scale of 1 to 10, and yours is a 1," and the next to the one he wrote in parentheses, "Worst," in case we thought maybe that was the top of his rating scale.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A vivid example of how brutally a pitch can fail when it doesn’t land with investors.

quotes.topic_title: Andy’s origin story: from coder to narrative
quotes.text: And he had written in, "Not a compelling story."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Pinpoints the core diagnosis: the issue wasn’t the idea alone, but the narrative.

quotes.topic_title: Andy’s origin story: from coder to narrative
quotes.text: I started reading these books and it strikes me a movie is a pitch.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Introduces a transferable mental model: treat storytelling structure as persuasive pitching structure.

quotes.topic_title: Andy’s origin story: from coder to narrative
quotes.text: That we didn't change the product, it was basically the same business just sort of how we talked about it.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Counterintuitive lesson that narrative framing can drive outcomes even without product changes.

quotes.topic_title: Solving your own problem creates opportunities
quotes.text: One is that interesting opportunities arise when you're doing something you're excited about.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical career heuristic: follow genuine excitement because it tends to surface unexpected opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Solving your own problem creates opportunities
quotes.text: So you had the startup, it didn't work out, but you had a problem that you solved for yourself and that led to another, a bigger opportunity for your career.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of turning a failed venture into career leverage by productizing (or sharing) a solution to a personal problem.

quotes.topic_title: Solving your own problem creates opportunities
quotes.text: And then also just some of the best opportunities arise from solving your own problem, not planning to start something with it, but just like, "I have a problem."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Counterintuitive advice: don’t start with a business plan—start by fixing your own pain point and let opportunities emerge.

quotes.topic_title: Solving your own problem creates opportunities
quotes.text: Yeah, that's how it goes. It always overnight for everyone else that isn't here.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Memorable reminder that “overnight success” is usually the outside view of a long, gradual build.

quotes.topic_title: Defining a strategic narrative and the old/new game
quotes.text: The one thing I say is it's this one story that the CEO uses to drive success in marketing, sales, but also product. That it becomes like a north star, strategic north star for product roadmap, for fundraising, for recruiting, really everything.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Defines strategic narrative as a single guiding story that aligns not just go-to-market, but the entire company’s priorities and decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Defining a strategic narrative and the old/new game
quotes.text: And the traditional structure, the way I learned how to pitch in business school, I think the way most people did is what I call the arrogant doctor. So you have a problem, a pain, I have a solution, a treatment, and I'm going to tell you why it's better than all the other treatment.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Names and crystallizes the common “problem-solution-brag” pitch pattern, making it easier to recognize and avoid when crafting narratives.

quotes.topic_title: Defining a strategic narrative and the old/new game
quotes.text: In the movies, every movie starts with some kind of shift in the world, in the character's world. And I call this shift the shift from the old game to the new game.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Introduces the “old game → new game” shift as a narrative structure that reframes positioning around change rather than features.

quotes.topic_title: Defining a strategic narrative and the old/new game
quotes.text: So he comes in and he says, "Hey, software is over," meaning software in the sense that we're going to own it and maintain it, "And there's this new world called the cloud, a new game, like the new rules, everything has changed and that's the new way to win. And we're going to help you if you're in there."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Concrete example (Salesforce) of leading with a market shift and new rules to create urgency and a movement customers can join.

quotes.topic_title: Defining a strategic narrative and the old/new game
quotes.text: This structure really is about defining a movement and that's very different from, "Hey, I'm going to solve your problem."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Contrasts movement-based narrative with conventional problem/solution framing, highlighting a more powerful positioning approach.

quotes.topic_title: Salesforce pitch: movement beats feature comparisons
quotes.text: They would've come and said, "Oh, we're easier to install, faster to get up and running than Siebel," or, "We have this much functionality compared to,"
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Highlights the default (and often weaker) playbook of feature/comparison selling against incumbents.

quotes.topic_title: Salesforce pitch: movement beats feature comparisons
quotes.text: They led with this story about this fundamental paradigm shift and, are you in or are you not in?
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A crisp framework for positioning: make the pitch about an inevitable shift and force a strategic choice.

quotes.topic_title: Salesforce pitch: movement beats feature comparisons
quotes.text: And what they did was instead of just saying, "Hey, we're better than," they said, "Hey, all those others, those Siebel's, they're part of that old game. You want to play that software game? Be my guest, go buy Siebel,"
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Shows how to reframe competition by redefining the category and casting incumbents as the past.

quotes.topic_title: Salesforce pitch: movement beats feature comparisons
quotes.text: So the crux of the approach is instead of, "Problem, solution, you should go do this," it's, "The world is changing, here's where it's going and we're going to help you get there."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Summarizes the strategic narrative method as a shift from tactical problem/solution to directional change leadership.

quotes.topic_title: More examples: Zuora and Gong narratives
quotes.text: So the crux of the approach is instead of, "Problem, solution, you should go do this," it's, "The world is changing, here's where it's going and we're going to help you get there."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A clear, reusable framing for shifting from feature/problem selling to a strategic narrative about change and direction.

quotes.topic_title: More examples: Zuora and Gong narratives
quotes.text: And he's pitching, "Hey, in the old world, businesses operated on transactions. You sold things to people outright. In this new world," he calls it the subscription economy, where people want the benefits of those things without necessarily having to pay for them.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A concrete example of the “old world vs new world” narrative structure that creates a movement customers can join.

quotes.topic_title: More examples: Zuora and Gong narratives
quotes.text: And that story is, hey, goodbye opinions. Used to be a world where sales is run on opinions. Hello reality, that now all the winners are adopting this new mindset where we really have to see what's really going on.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A memorable, repeatable movement slogan that positions a product as a mindset shift rather than a tool.

quotes.topic_title: More examples: Zuora and Gong narratives
quotes.text: There wasn't this kind of unifying kind of movement ideology that put it all in context.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Highlights the often-missing ingredient in effective go-to-market storytelling: a unifying ideology that contextualizes features and benefits.

quotes.topic_title: More examples: Zuora and Gong narratives
quotes.text: Initially, they were seen as a tool for sales operations, for someone who's going to record the calls and what this narrative did for them. And I think it was already starting to happen, but what it really coalesced was this is a tool for sales leadership.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Shows how a strategic narrative can expand category perception and shift the buyer/user from ops to leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Impact of Andy’s Zuora deck post and writing
quotes.text: So I was already doing this kind of work for a couple of years, but that post immediately got something like 2 million views around the world and I started getting inquiries from teams all over the world.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A concrete example of how a single high-distribution piece of writing can generate massive inbound demand globally.

quotes.topic_title: Impact of Andy’s Zuora deck post and writing
quotes.text: And it was I think what really allowed me to say no, okay, I could do this work. That CEO's would budget a line item for this.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Shows how viral content can validate willingness-to-pay and turn an expertise into a budgeted service offering.

quotes.topic_title: Impact of Andy’s Zuora deck post and writing
quotes.text: Because I think if you really understand that post, it's not really about a sales deck, it's really about this story that Tien, the CEO is telling everywhere and that is showing up in the sales deck and structuring it that way.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A reframing framework: treat the deck as an artifact of an overarching CEO narrative, not a standalone sales document.

quotes.topic_title: Impact of Andy’s Zuora deck post and writing
quotes.text: What started to happen, I think around when I started writing around 2013, '14, you start to see these platforms, like Medium, even LinkedIn where you can just write and have this audience and I think no way I could do this, the work I do if that development hadn't happened first.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Highlights the leverage of direct-to-audience distribution platforms as an enabler for independent practitioners.

quotes.topic_title: Impact of Andy’s Zuora deck post and writing
quotes.text: I find that there's kind of two paths to writing online. One is your path where you write one piece that just blows up like crazy. The other path is more my path where I just write consistently for a long time, and both work and most people try to go your path and they never succeed.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical mental model for content strategy that challenges the common “go viral” approach and emphasizes consistency as an alternative path.

quotes.topic_title: Writing growth: iteration, peaks, and consistency
quotes.text: So that was probably the 30th or 40th piece and they were gradually getting more and more traction.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Reframes “overnight success” as the result of many iterations and compounding audience growth.

quotes.topic_title: Writing growth: iteration, peaks, and consistency
quotes.text: So what I find is like, yeah, there's this a while where you're writing and it feels like you're talking to nobody and then gradually it grows and you'll have these peaks, but then over time is where the magic is.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A practical mental model for creators: expect a long low-feedback phase, then intermittent peaks, with results driven by time and consistency.

quotes.topic_title: Writing growth: iteration, peaks, and consistency
quotes.text: There was one I wrote before that about, it's kind of dissecting Elon Musk's pitch for the Powerwall, the battery that they sell. And that one got maybe few hundred thousand views and also was a big jump. And then the next one got some poultry number.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Concrete example that even after a breakout post, performance can swing wildly—so you can’t rely on a single “hit.”

quotes.topic_title: Writing growth: iteration, peaks, and consistency
quotes.text: I haven't done a newsletter because that idea of having a deadline all the time and constantly having to, we used to call the magazine Feed the Beast, I feel so free not to have that.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Counterintuitive advice: avoiding constant publishing deadlines can preserve creative freedom and sustainability.

quotes.topic_title: Strategic narrative framework: five core components
quotes.text: What's really, I think key is naming it, naming that old game.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Highlights the first core move in the framework: make the change concrete by crisply labeling the prior paradigm.

quotes.topic_title: Strategic narrative framework: five core components
quotes.text: So we're always kind of overstating it in a way, but it's not a problem.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance that strategic narratives can (and should) simplify/overstate to create clarity without getting derailed by edge cases.

quotes.topic_title: Strategic narrative framework: five core components
quotes.text: The second piece is what I call naming the stakes.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Defines the second component: explicitly frame what’s at risk so the audience feels urgency and consequence.

quotes.topic_title: Strategic narrative framework: five core components
quotes.text: We got to show them that the future is not going to just be sort of okay.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Actionable advice for creating urgency: make the status-quo future unacceptable rather than merely suboptimal.

quotes.topic_title: Strategic narrative framework: five core components
quotes.text: The fourth piece is, okay, well this object of the game, winning this game, it better be hard because if it's not, why would we even exist?
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A practical test for positioning: your “new game” must include real obstacles, or the narrative (and your value) collapses.

quotes.topic_title: Hero’s journey parallels and making buyer the hero
quotes.text: But even that aside, I found when I would talk about hero's journey and stuff, it's just like, it didn't really tell me what to do.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Highlights a practical critique of the hero’s journey as too abstract for real-world pitching, pushing practitioners toward more actionable structures.

quotes.topic_title: Hero’s journey parallels and making buyer the hero
quotes.text: I'm not really interested in that in my work, what I'm interested in is the one story and the structure of that one story.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Reframes storytelling from a general skill to designing a single, repeatable strategic narrative structure.

quotes.topic_title: Hero’s journey parallels and making buyer the hero
quotes.text: It's almost as if what's happening is we're turning the person we talk to into the main character. By spelling out the shift, we're changing their world and we're saying, "Hey, you got to change and you want to come with us."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Core methodology: make the buyer the hero by defining a market shift that forces a decision and invites them into the journey.

quotes.topic_title: Hero’s journey parallels and making buyer the hero
quotes.text: And by the way, the naming of the object of the new game, I find it often is really nice to do it as a question.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Actionable tactic for pitches: frame the “new game” as a question to pull the buyer into co-creating the narrative.

quotes.topic_title: Hero’s journey parallels and making buyer the hero
quotes.text: So we asked a simple question, what would it take to turn every customer into a subscriber?
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Concrete example of the “object of the new game as a question” technique that makes the shift feel participatory and urgent.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Last month Eco users earned an average of $84 in cash back rewards.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete performance metric that can be used as a benchmark or proof point in marketing and product positioning.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eco is the update to a misaligned financial system providing an app that works just like your bank but removes almost all of the middlemen, helping even the best money optimizers optimize in less time automatically.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A clear positioning statement that pairs “familiar experience” with a differentiated mechanism (removing middlemen) and a specific user benefit (time saved automatically).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What if you earn rewards for paying your rent or got rewarded for ordering food and shopping online or even earn rewards for saving each month?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical messaging pattern—use “What if” scenarios to expand the perceived surface area of value into everyday behaviors.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Maybe just to reinforce this even more, what if we go through the five steps and just with one company as an example and just talk about what each of those were for them?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: An applied-teaching tactic: reinforce a framework by walking through it end-to-end using a single concrete case study.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So there's a company called 360Learning. So this company, I don't know if folks know, but this company is raised over $200 million.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A specific example and credibility marker that sets up a real-world case study for applying the “five steps” framework.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: 360Learning narrative in practice
quotes.text: And so when we worked together this collaborative learning, it's almost like a category name or a descriptor or something. They were so embedded that I decided, I don't even want to take it out, but can we define it in terms of a story?
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Shows a practical positioning move: keep familiar category language, but make it meaningful by anchoring it in a narrative shift.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: 360Learning narrative in practice
quotes.text: So the story they came to was, hey, used to be that companies train their people through basically a mindset of top-down learning.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Illustrates the core strategic narrative pattern of contrasting an old world with a new world to create urgency and clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: 360Learning narrative in practice
quotes.text: What's happening now is winning companies are approaching this differently. They're adopting this approach we might call upskill from within,
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Provides a memorable “new way” label that practitioners can use to frame a market shift and differentiate beyond features.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: 360Learning narrative in practice
quotes.text: Nick was in France and he saw this poster, a recruiting poster from McDonald's and it said, "Hey, if you work at McDonald's you're going to learn from everybody else on your team."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A concrete, surprising example of “upskill from within” showing how to support a narrative with vivid real-world proof points.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: 360Learning narrative in practice
quotes.text: he was telling me it's just like when he starts with this now he doesn't even get the question anymore of well how are you different from this other learning platform?
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Captures the outcome metric of a strong narrative: it preempts commoditization by changing the buyer’s frame of comparison.

quotes.topic_title: Business impact: marketing, sales, and product alignment
quotes.text: One is that when they're pitching, they're not pitching features out of context, they're pitching now a movement which is a lot better place to be, I think.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Reframes sales positioning from feature-led demos to movement-led narratives that create a higher-level conversation.

quotes.topic_title: Business impact: marketing, sales, and product alignment
quotes.text: In a way you're not pitching product. Product is like a prop for making the story come true.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for aligning sales and marketing around a narrative where the product supports (rather than leads) the pitch.

quotes.topic_title: Business impact: marketing, sales, and product alignment
quotes.text: With Zuora, if you look at their website, well when they first started doing this, maybe 80% of the content is not, "Hey, let me tell you about how Zuora is so great," or, "Here's our new release," or whatever. It's, "Here's how music companies are embracing subscriptions. Here's how luxury goods companies are embracing subscriptions."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Concrete example of using narrative-driven, trend-based content to generate scalable, non-product-centric marketing material.

quotes.topic_title: Business impact: marketing, sales, and product alignment
quotes.text: It becomes the strategic north star for the product.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Shows how a strategic narrative can become a product decision filter, aligning prioritization across sales, CS, and product.

quotes.topic_title: Business impact: marketing, sales, and product alignment
quotes.text: We are constantly getting feature requests through sales, through customer success. And we had sort of no way, bar to decide well what do we take on, what don't we take on? And this clearly has become our bar.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Actionable product-alignment method: use the narrative as the explicit bar for accepting or rejecting feature requests.

quotes.topic_title: Strong narrative example: Drift and conversational marketing
quotes.text: Drift comes out with essentially like a chatbot for your website, which might be the 30th chatbot for your website. And they don't say, "Hey, here's why our chatbot is the best one." They start from a completely different place, which is, "Hey, used to be people would sort of wait around for you to get back to them. It was a world of later. They called it the world of forms."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Shows a differentiation playbook: avoid feature wars and instead reframe the market with a new “world” narrative.

quotes.topic_title: Strong narrative example: Drift and conversational marketing
quotes.text: You put up a web form and you expect someone's going to fill it out and maybe wait a few days while you take your sweet time deciding if you're going to get back to them.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A concrete description of the old status quo that practitioners can use to set up a compelling “before vs after” narrative.

quotes.topic_title: Strong narrative example: Drift and conversational marketing
quotes.text: Now we're in a world of now, where buyers are ... I think they showed this woman, I remember it was this woman sleeping with her phone. That's your prospect. They're always on and they're going to expect you to be engaging with them right away.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Illustrates how to anchor a narrative in a vivid customer behavior shift to justify urgency and product approach.

quotes.topic_title: Strong narrative example: Drift and conversational marketing
quotes.text: And they called this conversational marketing, and they really went with that and created I think a whole movement and they broke away from all of the other chatbots.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Highlights the tactic of naming the new approach to create a movement and escape commoditized competition.

quotes.topic_title: Category creation vs movement and narrative
quotes.text: what I find though is that when people think about category creation, they tend to just focus on, okay, well, what is this category name going to be that we got? What are these three words or two words, whatever, that are going to magically make us seem like we're totally different from everybody else?
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Challenges the common “category naming” fixation and reframes differentiation as something deeper than a label.

quotes.topic_title: Category creation vs movement and narrative
quotes.text: And A, I think that's not really possible. These three words aren't going to do it.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A blunt, actionable warning that naming alone won’t create meaningful market separation.

quotes.topic_title: Category creation vs movement and narrative
quotes.text: Take Gong, I mean already other companies were using this term revenue intelligence. With Gong, it suddenly becomes a thing because I think they have this opinions-to-reality story behind it.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Concrete example showing how narrative (not terminology) is what makes a “category” stick.

quotes.topic_title: Category creation vs movement and narrative
quotes.text: "Yeah, you know what? In hindsight we probably could have called it strawberry intelligence. It didn't matter. It was really the story that sort of mattered."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Memorable line that crystallizes the idea that the movement story drives adoption more than the category label.

quotes.topic_title: Category creation vs movement and narrative
quotes.text: So my feeling is like, well, let's focus on the story. So that's why I talk about strategic narrative and movement creation versus category creation. If someone decides that your movement is a category, great. Bonus.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Practical prioritization framework: build the movement narrative first and treat category designation as a byproduct.

quotes.topic_title: Where strategic narrative fits best (and where it doesn’t)
quotes.text: So I think it does really play well in this enterprise sales context because also we have a group buyer there. So it's not just one person who's doing some research. This whole group has to have a uniting story.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Explains why strategic narrative is especially effective in enterprise sales: it aligns multiple stakeholders around a shared story.

quotes.topic_title: Where strategic narrative fits best (and where it doesn’t)
quotes.text: That arrogant doctor stuff comes from an age when the things people were selling were products on shelves that didn't change much, cans of soup at the supermarket or a car in a dealership. Even software back then, shrink-wrapped in a box, doesn't change.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Contrasts static, spec-driven selling with modern markets, implying narrative becomes more necessary as products and categories evolve faster.

quotes.topic_title: Where strategic narrative fits best (and where it doesn’t)
quotes.text: B2B software, this stuff is changing by the minute. And does it even make sense to make a claim to say, "Oh, we have these features and they have those features, therefore we're better," does that make any sense?
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Challenges the default feature-comparison approach in fast-changing B2B software and motivates shifting to narrative-based differentiation.

quotes.topic_title: Where strategic narrative fits best (and where it doesn’t)
quotes.text: That said, hey, I was looking for a sports watch, a Fitbit and I'm comparing specs and I'm doing all that stuff. And so that mode of buying is still happening, but I think, so yeah, when consumer products companies contact me, I usually say, "No."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Gives a concrete example of when spec/feature comparison still wins and offers practical guidance on when not to use strategic narrative.

quotes.topic_title: Signals you need a narrative refresh
quotes.text: I always ask, what's happening? Because that idea I had, no CEO's going to budget a line item for this. I'm basically asking, why was I wrong?
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic framing: treat narrative work as a response to concrete business pain, not a discretionary branding project.

quotes.topic_title: Signals you need a narrative refresh
quotes.text: one is that the company is maturing from a point a stage where they've been successful, but that success is ... one CEO put it this way, was brute force of the founders.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Highlights a common trigger for narrative refresh: founder-driven momentum stops scaling, so the story must carry the load.

quotes.topic_title: Signals you need a narrative refresh
quotes.text: Usually I'm seeing this around series B where the company is getting ... so they can't be in every sales call, every market call and they're looking to transmit all the good stuff and some direction in a way that people are going to remember and all that.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Gives a concrete stage marker (Series B) and an actionable goal for narrative: make direction memorable and repeatable beyond the founders.

quotes.topic_title: Signals you need a narrative refresh
quotes.text: Now we're either acquiring or building out whole new product units. And that old story we told is just, it's just not big enough and we got to expand it to something bigger.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A clear heuristic: when product scope expands via acquisition/new units, the narrative must expand to match the new company shape.

quotes.topic_title: Signals you need a narrative refresh
quotes.text: And I guess the third one is some form of pivot where hey, we were telling an old story but whatever, the market changed or whatever and we want to go in a different direction.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Defines a third trigger for refreshing narrative: market shifts force a directional change, making the old story obsolete.

quotes.topic_title: How to start: draft, test in calls, avoid templates
quotes.text: I want to get that thing out there into sales calls. We're not rolling it out to the whole sales team right away, but getting it out into some sales calls and get a sense, "Hey, is this resonating? Are people given the nods?"
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A lean, low-risk way to validate your narrative by piloting it in a few real conversations before scaling.

quotes.topic_title: How to start: draft, test in calls, avoid templates
quotes.text: Ideally by the way, one way I look to test it, is it working, is when we talk about this shift and the stakes and do they stick.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A concrete qualitative test: prospects should engage specifically with your “shift” and “stakes,” not just the product.

quotes.topic_title: How to start: draft, test in calls, avoid templates
quotes.text: Sometimes I'll literally, I'll train salespeople to ask them that question, like, "Am I crazy or are you seeing this?"
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A simple prompt to elicit honest validation and get prospects to confirm (or reject) your framing in their own words.

quotes.topic_title: How to start: draft, test in calls, avoid templates
quotes.text: And I am so against this template. Every team I work with, it's different.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A contrarian stance against one-size-fits-all decks, emphasizing narrative must be tailored to each team and market.

quotes.topic_title: How to start: draft, test in calls, avoid templates
quotes.text: And what I'd say is these are principles for building it, not any prescribed formula.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Reframes the work as applying adaptable principles rather than following a rigid step-by-step template.
